awd_titl_txt: Single Molecule Electrophoresis using Nanochannel Columns Fabricated in Thermoplastics
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program of the Division of Chemistry as well as by the Global Ventures Fund of the Office of International Science and Engineering is supporting Professor Steven A. Soper of the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill  to develop new insights into the use of plastic-based columns for nanoscale separations, such as electrophoresis. Activities include: understanding techniques to produce nano-columns in plastics using imprinting (the same technique used to produce DVD disks), modifying the surface properties of plastics and finally, using plastic columns with nanometer dimensions to undertake separations with unique operating characteristics. The broader impacts are demonstrated in part through the application utility of nanoscale electrophoresis in a number of compelling areas such as DNA or RNA sequencing, which can provide information on variations in the sequence content of a DNA/RNA molecule induced by environmental effects, identifying biopathogens, and/or looking for strain-specific bacterial or viral infections. The project team is comprised of researchers at the University of North Carolina (USA) and at Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology (UNIST) in South Korea, who have established a productive research collaboration. UNC graduate students participating in this project will spend 12 months at UNIST to work on specific aims of this collaborative project, taking advantage of the research infrastructure and expertise at UNIST and experiencing a truly global research environment.

This project takes a multi-disciplinary approach that includes transcriptomics, RNA/DNA sequencing, and detection of epigenetic sequence variations in DNA to develop the area of single-molecule electrophoresis using nanometer columns. The columns that are employed are unusual in that they contain nanochannels with nano-dimensions (<200 nm) in width and depth, but lengths of >50 µm.  These are fabricated in thermoplastics using nanoimprint lithography. The electrophoresis of both small molecules and biopolymers are investigated by monitoring the transport of the appropriately prepared targets; the targets are labeled with fluorogenic tags so that the transport dynamics can be monitored using particle tracking and fluorescence microscopy for longitudinal motions or super-resolution fluorescence imaging for determining transverse electromigration. A host of surface modifications are invoked on the nanochannels to understand the effects of surface charge density and the homogeneity of these modifications on the transport dynamics of single molecules. While these modification strategies have been demonstrated in microchannels, they are yet unproven in nanochannels. The transport of both molecule types are undertaken using new formats of 'super-resolution' microscopy that aims to achieve unprecedented sensitivity, and spatial and time resolution.  The technique may also help to elucidate electrokinetic transport properties in the case where column dimensions are similar to the Debye length.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: University of Kansas Center for Research Inc
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF KANSAS CENTER FOR RESEARCH INC

por.por_cntn:
• We have generated simple and robust methods to produce nanometer scale structures in plastics using nanoimprint lithography (NIL). In addition, a thermal assembly approach was developed that can allow for the generation of nanofluidic devices in plastics in a high production mode and at low cost as well. These discoveries will allow for the dissemination of this technology into a broader user community compared to glass-based devices, which requires the use of sophisticated equipment to make each device (FIB, EBL or the like). We are now learning how to generate these structures using injection molding that will dramatically improve device production rate and at the same time lower device cost.

 

  • We have successfully built two single-molecule fluorescence systems to determine the dynamics of single molecule transport through polymer-based nanofluidic channels. One is an imaging microscope and the other is a dual beam system for measuring the electrophoretic mobility of single molecules with high bandwidth for investigating electric field strength effects on the transport and dispersion properties of single molecules. Both instruments have been used to track the transport dynamics of fluorescently-labeled single molecules (small molecules and large molecules).

 

  • We have developed the ability to and a broad understanding of the surface activation process for a variety of polymeric materials using either UV/O3 or O2 plasma. These activation processes allow for the generation of surface charge on the polymer, improving its wettability, which can be used for any analytical assay requiring aqueous solvents, such as electrophoresis. Interestingly, these activation protocols can also generate functional groups to allow for the further modification of the surface, such as covalently appending chemical species to the surfaces. In addition, a detailed study of the effects of the activation process on functional group heterogeneity was deduced using superresolution microscopy. While surface heterogeneity was found, the low intrinsic surface charge associated with most polymeric species minimizes this artifact in terms of the electrophoretic performance.

 

  • We have performed and demonstrated unique electrophoretic separations of both single NPs and molecules using polymer-based nanocolumns. AgNPs of 60 and 100 nm could be separated in free solution using a PMMA nanocolumn at low ionic strengths, high electric fields and slits with dimensions on the order of 1600 nm. This separation required a micellar phase to affect the separation using microscale columns. We were also able to demonstrate the ability to separate dye-labeled mononucleotides in free solution using nanoscale electrophoresis.   

 

  • We have performed high resolution single-molecule separations of small molecules (deoxynucleotide monophosphates and ribonucleotide monophosphates) and large molecules (oligonucleotides) using nanoscale electrophoresis. In the case of the small molecules, the separations were found to be based primarily on differences in the electrophoretic mobility of the molecules whereas in the case of the large molecules, the separation was a combination of electrophoresis and chromatography, which we have coined nanochannel electrochromatography.  In the case of the oligonucleotides, baseline separation was accomplished in plastic nanochannels (80 x 80 nm, width x depth) with the degree of separation quality dependent on the type of thermoplastic used. We demonstrated that cyclic olefin copolymer (COC) was a better substrate choice for this separation compared to PMMA. We also determined that the channel length was critical to provide high quality separations. When the separation was performed in a microchannel, the oligonucleotides comigrated due to their free draining behavior, but in the nanochannel made from COC baseline separation was achieved. Because the double layer thickness for this separation was ~1.5 nm, there was no electrical double layer overlap and as such, the flow is purely plug-like. Thus, chromatographic effects were in play as well to afford the favorable separation results.

 

  •        We developed a new method for the assembly and surface activation of polymer-based nanofluidic devices. We found that we could thermally fusion bond a COC cover plate with a low glass transition temperature to a different grade of COC with a higher glass transition temperature. The resulting devices had a process yield rate >90% and could be surface activated following device assembly using UV/O3 light. This will allow for the careful control of the electroosmotic flow (EOF) for nanofluidic devices that can have a profound impact on electrophoresis performance.

 

  •        We have started the development of label-free readout strategies for single molecules that will negate the need for fluorescence labeling of molecules undergoing nanoscale electrophoresis. The label-free readout uses in-plane nanopores (2-10 nm in width and depth) that flank either side of the nanochannel column and can deduce the electrophoretic mobility of the single molecule undergoing electrophoresis. The in-plane pores are made in the same step as the nanochannel column using NIL.

Last Modified: 01/16/2020
Modified by: Steven A Soper
por.por_txt_cntn:
We have generated simple and robust methods to produce nanometer scale structures in plastics using nanoimprint lithography (NIL). In addition, a thermal assembly approach was developed that can allow for the generation of nanofluidic devices in plastics in a high production mode and at low cost as well. These discoveries will allow for the dissemination of this technology into a broader user community compared to glass-based devices, which requires the use of sophisticated equipment to make each device (FIB, EBL or the like). We are now learning how to generate these structures using injection molding that will dramatically improve device production rate and at the same time lower device cost. 


 

We have successfully built two single-molecule fluorescence systems to determine the dynamics of single molecule transport through polymer-based nanofluidic channels. One is an imaging microscope and the other is a dual beam system for measuring the electrophoretic mobility of single molecules with high bandwidth for investigating electric field strength effects on the transport and dispersion properties of single molecules. Both instruments have been used to track the transport dynamics of fluorescently-labeled single molecules (small molecules and large molecules). 


 

We have developed the ability to and a broad understanding of the surface activation process for a variety of polymeric materials using either UV/O3 or O2 plasma. These activation processes allow for the generation of surface charge on the polymer, improving its wettability, which can be used for any analytical assay requiring aqueous solvents, such as electrophoresis. Interestingly, these activation protocols can also generate functional groups to allow for the further modification of the surface, such as covalently appending chemical species to the surfaces. In addition, a detailed study of the effects of the activation process on functional group heterogeneity was deduced using superresolution microscopy. While surface heterogeneity was found, the low intrinsic surface charge associated with most polymeric species minimizes this artifact in terms of the electrophoretic performance.


 

We have performed and demonstrated unique electrophoretic separations of both single NPs and molecules using polymer-based nanocolumns. AgNPs of 60 and 100 nm could be separated in free solution using a PMMA nanocolumn at low ionic strengths, high electric fields and slits with dimensions on the order of 1600 nm. This separation required a micellar phase to affect the separation using microscale columns. We were also able to demonstrate the ability to separate dye-labeled mononucleotides in free solution using nanoscale electrophoresis.   


 

We have performed high resolution single-molecule separations of small molecules (deoxynucleotide monophosphates and ribonucleotide monophosphates) and large molecules (oligonucleotides) using nanoscale electrophoresis. In the case of the small molecules, the separations were found to be based primarily on differences in the electrophoretic mobility of the molecules whereas in the case of the large molecules, the separation was a combination of electrophoresis and chromatography, which we have coined nanochannel electrochromatography.  In the case of the oligonucleotides, baseline separation was accomplished in plastic nanochannels (80 x 80 nm, width x depth) with the degree of separation quality dependent on the type of thermoplastic used. We demonstrated that cyclic olefin copolymer (COC) was a better substrate choice for this separation compared to PMMA. We also determined that the channel length was critical to provide high quality separations. When the separation was performed in a microchannel, the oligonucleotides comigrated due to their free draining behavior, but in the nanochannel made from COC baseline separation was achieved. Because the double layer thickness for this separation was ~1.5 nm, there was no electrical double layer overlap and as such, the flow is purely plug-like. Thus, chromatographic effects were in play as well to afford the favorable separation results.


 

       We developed a new method for the assembly and surface activation of polymer-based nanofluidic devices. We found that we could thermally fusion bond a COC cover plate with a low glass transition temperature to a different grade of COC with a higher glass transition temperature. The resulting devices had a process yield rate >90% and could be surface activated following device assembly using UV/O3 light. This will allow for the careful control of the electroosmotic flow (EOF) for nanofluidic devices that can have a profound impact on electrophoresis performance.


 

       We have started the development of label-free readout strategies for single molecules that will negate the need for fluorescence labeling of molecules undergoing nanoscale electrophoresis. The label-free readout uses in-plane nanopores (2-10 nm in width and depth) that flank either side of the nanochannel column and can deduce the electrophoretic mobility of the single molecule undergoing electrophoresis. The in-plane pores are made in the same step as the nanochannel column using NIL.
